item.title: CoD: Black Ops 6 Zombies - Citadelle des Morts Trailer Brings Back A Familiar Face
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/cod-black-ops-6-zombies-citadelle-des-morts-trailer-brings-back-a-familiar-face/1100-6528064/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 didn't make fans wait for the first two zombie maps, which launched alongside the game at the end of October. The next stop on the roadmap is Citadelle des Morts, a massive French castle in Avalon. The storyline continues with the Requiem crew after their escape from Terminus. And in the first cinematic trailer for the new map, the team runs into an old friend, Sergei Ravenov.

Most of the trailer takes place from Sergei's perspective, and he's genuinely surprised to see his old allies alive. But this isn't a social call, as the team is looking for a man named Craft who "may be able to bring back Maxis." Presumably they're referring to Samantha Maxis, an adversary-turned-ally before her untimely demise when she sacrificed herself to seal the Dark Aether portal.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Call Of Duty: Black Ops 6 - Citadelle des Morts Zombies Cinematic Trailer

Sergei seems to be intrigued by Maya Aguinaldo, the team's new addition. However, he's less than thrilled to see that they're working with William Peck. The team's goals may align with Peck's for now, but he's almost certainly going to betray them at some point, even if he did arrange their escape from Terminus.

The Citadelle des Morts map will launch on December 5, and the main story quest will go live simultaneously. Treyarch previously shared details about the new perks and the classic zombie features that will be included in this map. The Zombies campaign is just a small part of the ongoing Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 Season 1 roadmap, as Activision and Treyarch plan to keep players engaged for as long as possible.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: The Witcher 4 Is Now Officially In Production, New Teaser Image Revealed
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-witcher-4-is-now-officially-in-production-new-teaser-image-revealed/1100-6528058/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Project Polaris, the codename for the next Witcher game, has crossed a major milestone: It's now officially in full production. CD Projekt made the announcement today, November 26, as part of the company's wider earnings briefing.

Game director Sebastian Kalemba said the game--unofficially know as The Witcher 4--has "entered the full-scale production phase," following a period of pre-production. "With new challenges just around the corner, it's the talented and hard-working people who make me believe we can together make the upcoming Witcher Saga a remarkable experience. No stopping now! Stay tuned for what's on the other side of the coin!," he said.

I'm thrilled to announce that Project Polaris has entered the full-scale production phase! With new challenges just around the corner, it’s the talented and hard-working people who make me believe we can together make the upcoming Witcher Saga a remarkable experience. No stopping… pic.twitter.com/2pJdsg2sWX

— Sebastian Kalemba (@Skalemba) November 26, 2024

The majority of CD Projekt's development staff, totaling 400 of 650 total staffers, are now working on Polaris. This is actually down from 410 people as of July 31, 2024, before the game entered full production.

CD Projekt has a number of other games in the works, too, including Orion (the next Cyberpunk game), which has 64 people working on it now. Then there's Sirius (a Witcher spin-off) that has 32 people working on it. A total of 15 people are working on Hadar (a new IP), while other staff are contributing to "shared services" and other projects. You can see a headcount breakdown in the graphic below.

Not much is known about The Witcher 4, or whatever the game might be called. Management previously indicated, back in 2022, that The Witcher 4 would be released in 2025 at the very soonest, but this plan could have changed since then.

As for the story, we know Geralt will be in the game, though he won't be the focus of the narrative. Joint-CEO Michał Nowakowski previously said The Witcher 4 is not going to be "The Witcher 3 in new clothing." It aims to break new ground and stand apart from the games that came before it.

Also during the earnings report, CD Projekt announced that Cyberpunk 2077 has now sold 30 million copies, with its Phantom Liberty expansion shifting 8 million copies.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: This GameCube-Inspired Mechanical Keyboard Hits Lowest Price Ever For Black Friday
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/this-gamecube-inspired-mechanical-keyboard-hits-lowest-price-ever-for-black-friday/1100-6528055/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Need to bring a pop of color to your PC setup? Then pick up the NYXI Striker Retro Mechanical Keyboard, as the GameCube-inspired gadget is now just $80 (was $100) for Black Friday. That’s the best price we’ve ever seen for the unique keyboard--and with a bright purple frame along with white and yellow accents, it’ll quickly become the focal point of any home office.

NYXI Striker Retro Mechanical Keyboard

$80 (was $100)

With support for Bluetooth, 2.4GHz connections, and a USB wired mode, the NYXI Striker works on PC, Android, Mac, iOS, and iPad. Its hot-swappable switches make it highly customizable, while the backlit keyboard gives you plenty of ways to change its appearance. Toss in a dot matrix screen that can be personalized with different images and a vibrant purple design, and it’s a pretty compelling keyboard at just $80.

Several other NYXI devices are on sale for Black Friday, including several GameCube-inspired controllers for both Switch and PC. The NYXI Warrior is a traditional gamepad that’s a good alternative to the Switch Pro, while the NYXI Wizard is more akin to a Joy-Con replacement, as it can also be used in handheld mode.

There’s even an 8BitDo Retro Mechanical Keyboard on sale for $86 (was $110), so give it a look if the NYXI Striker is too flashy for your tastes.

Black Friday NYXI and 8BitDo Deals

  • NYXI Warrior Wireless: Orange (Switch, GC, Wii, PC) -- $48 ($69)
  • NYXI Warrior Wireless: Black (Switch, GC, Wii, PC) -- $55 ($69)
  • NYXI Warrior Wireless: Purple (Switch, GC, Wii, PC) -- $55 ($69)
  • NYXI Wizard: Spice Orange (Switch) -- $49 ($70)
  • NYXI Wizard: Silver (Switch) -- $49 ($70)
  • 8BitDo Retro Mechanical Keyboard (C64 Edition) -- $86 ($110)

item.title: Pokemon Go Developer Doesn't Want Its AI Mapping Data Used For War
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/pokemon-go-developer-doesnt-want-its-ai-mapping-data-used-for-war/1100-6528057/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Pokemon Go players recently learned that the game's developer, Niantic, is using their data to create a 3D model of the world before expanding it into a Large Geospatial Model with AI. Niantic is hoping to monetize this data, but even at this early stage, the company realizes that this could be put to use in unintended ways, including during war time.

As reported by 404 Media, Niantic Senior Vice President of Engineering Brian McClendon was asked about a military application of the company's Large Geospatial Model during the Bellingcat’s Bellingfest event.

"I could definitely see it," said McClendon. "I think the question is would there be anything that they would do with it that would be outside of what a consumer or a Bellingcat want to do with it. If the use case is identical, then that seems completely fine. If the use case is specific in military and adding amplitude to war then that's obviously an issue."

Take, for example, the ongoing war in Ukraine. If Russia had access to complete 3D models of Ukraine's cities and countryside, it would give the invading country a tactical advantage that it doesn't currently have. For now, Niantic hasn't ruled out selling its LGM data to governments in the future.

"The LGM is an early stage project and is months or even years away from any kind of product," noted a Niantic spokesperson when asked about the possibility of selling the data. "Just like any kind of AI, there will be important questions that arise and we'll tackle those responsibly and thoughtfully."

For now, we don't have to worry about Pikachu and the other Pokemon being used to map out current combat zones in the near future. Niantic's early map of the LGM model appears to be largely composed of locations in North America and Europe, while the rest of the world is a long way from being completed.

One of the franchise's other mobile games, Pokemon Trading Card Game Pocket, recently attracted 30 million downloads in its first week alone. Additionally, Pokemon Gold and Silver now has a line of 25th- anniversary merchandise. But fans will have to wait until 2025 for Pokemon Legends Z-A, one of the next games in the series.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Activision Bans Thousands Of Black Ops 6 Ranked Players, But Some Say It's Not Enough
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/activision-bans-thousands-of-black-ops-6-ranked-players-but-some-say-its-not-enough/1100-6528056/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Activision has responded to concerns about Call of Duty: Black Ops 6's Ranked playlist, and specifically the efforts being undertaken to try to thwart cheaters. The company says it's banned thousands of players and is banning more people every hour, but some popular streamers have spoken out to voice their ongoing concerns.

In a statement, Activision said the AI-powered systems in Call of Duty's anti-cheat technology, Ricochet, "continue to ramp up with code optimizations" that aim to "accelerate enforcements" against bad actors. Since Ranked play launched last week, Activision has banned more than 19,000 people, and Ricochet is doing "hourly sweeps" to kick more cheaters out.

Activision has always said the fight against cheaters is an ongoing battle, and one that may never be solved completely. Popular streamer Nadeshot responded to the statement, saying it's "complete propaganda" from his vantage point.

"Ten names minimum in the first three pages we're legitimately spin-botting LIVE on our streams. How could there possibly be 19K accounts banned when the most egregious abusers are giving us the middle finger on the leaderboard? Are we crazy? What is going on," he said.

Another popular streamer, Westie, said Activision's Ricochet updates are ineffective and that they "result in absolutely zero change to the gameplay experience." He also said cheating remains a problem in Warzone. "It feels like the anti-cheat has been turned off," he said.

Another issue that Call of Duty fans have surfaced is that the Ranked mode on console forces players to use cross-play, which puts them into matches with PC players. A mouse-and-keyboard setup is understood to be the most precise way to play a FPS like Call of Duty, and many have voiced concerns about a "level playing field" when people on console, using a controller, are forced to play against people using mouse and keyboard. Then there is the issue of cheating, as it's generally easier to install cheat software on PC compared to console.

In other Call of Duty news, Activision recently reduced the player cap for Warzone's new map, Area 99. Activision also announced that Black Ops 6 had the biggest launch in franchise history, thanks in part to Game Pass.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
